intro: Ranunculus geraniifolius var. mesatlanticus, commonly known as the Atlantic meadow buttercup, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows, marshes, and stream banks. The plant features delicate, palmately divided leaves and bright yellow flowers with five petals. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family, characterized by its showy flowers and often toxic sap. Its botanical structure supports its role in local ecosystems, providing food for pollinators and stabilizing soil in wetland areas.
